title: Complete raw identifier help suggestion for all applicable keywords used as identifiers

labels.name: A-diagnostics
labels.description: Area: Messages for errors, warnings, and lints

labels.name: T-compiler
labels.description: Relevant to the compiler team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

body:
<!--
Thank you for filing a bug report! 🐛 Please provide a short summary of the bug,
along with any information you feel relevant to replicating the bug.

If you cannot produce a minimal reproduction case (something that would work in
isolation), please provide the steps or even link to a repository that causes
the problematic output to occur.
-->

Given the following code: [link](https://play.rust-lang.org/?version=nightly&mode=debug&edition=2021&gist=576d9ef1b3ae7e78337fb17b80f8d125)

```rust
fn main() {
    let false = 1;
    let in = 2;
    let mut = 3;
    let ref = 4;
    let true = 5;
}
```

The current output is:

```
Compiling playground v0.0.1 (/playground)
error: expected pattern, found keyword `in`
 --> src/main.rs:3:9
  |
3 |     let in = 2;
  |         ^^ expected pattern

error[[E0308]](https://doc.rust-lang.org/nightly/error-index.html#E0308): mismatched types
 --> src/main.rs:2:9
  |
2 |     let false = 1;
  |         ^^^^^   - this expression has type `{integer}`
  |         |
  |         expected integer, found `bool`

For more information about this error, try `rustc --explain E0308`.
error: could not compile `playground` due to 2 previous errors
```

<!-- The following is not always necessary. -->
Out of all the keywords (strict, reserved and weak), all of them suggest adding the `r#` prefix to make it a raw identifier when used in the above setting, except the ones listed above or those that cant be made into a raw identifier (I just tested all of them). Hence, I think we should extend the raw identifier suggestion to all applicable keywords listed above in the code snippet. This ensures uniformity across the board with regards to this help suggestion. The help suggestion may look like the following (the format for all  help suggestions currently present). Thanks a lot.

```
help: escape `false` to use it as an identifier
  |
2 |     let r#false = 1;
  |         ++
```

<!--
If the problem is not self-explanatory, please provide a rationale for the
change.
-->

If dramatically different output is caused by small changes, consider also
